title: Ticketek owner acquired by US private equity giant
text:
Mr Jones told AFR Weekend the MJR Group deal is the first of a number of options on the table in Europe.

"The initial focus will be on really big expansion into the UK and Europe and continues growth into Asia," he said.

TEG was advised by Goldman Sachs and King & Wood Mallesons, while Silver Lake took advice from Latham & Watkins and Corrs Chambers Westgarth. The financial terms of the deal were not released.

“The team at Affinity have been great partners for us over the last four years and have helped us to continue to scale our business," Mr Jones said.

“We are confident that Silver Lake is the right partner for the next stage of the company’s growth. Silver Lake brings us deep technology expertise as well as important global entertainment content and live events expertise and relationships which will help us to accelerate the growth of our platform globally.”

Mr Jones and his management team will continue running the company and will remain equity partners under the Silver Lake ownership.

Silver Lake managing director Stephen Evans said the firm believed TEG is well placed to capitalise on the growing live sports and entertainment market globally.

“We’ve been impressed by TEG’s long-term track record of growth under Geoff Jones, most recently in partnership with the Affinity team, both organically and through strategic acquisitions," he said in a statement.

"We’re excited to partner with Geoff and the entire TEG team and invest further to leverage TEG’s platform and accelerate the company’s growth, both in Asia Pacific and globally.”

Silver Lake is a US-based private equity firm with offices in Silicon Valley, California and New York. Its other investments include Madison Square Garden, the Ultimate Fighting Championship (UFC), Dell Technologies, Alibaba Group and Endeavor.

TEG acquired a number of businesses throughout the Asia-Pacific after Nine, owner of The Australian Financial Review, sold the business – then known as Nine Live – to private equity firm Affinity Equity Partners in 2015 for $640 million.

In 2016, TEG purchased touring business The Dainty Group, which produces and promotes shows in Australia, New Zealand, southeast Asia, the UK and South Africa, and is considered among the world's top promoters.

It also acquired Life Like Touring, a children's show touring business, and The Entertainment Store, which is a licensee for live performances by brands including Disney, 21st Century Fox, Sesame Workshop, Sony and Warner Bros.
description: Australian ticketing, live events and data analytics business TEG has been sold in a deal worth more than $1 billion to US private equity giant Silver Lake.
